content: in the LinkedIn context and I suspect most of the people in this room have read the LinkedIn series bedeck you should if you haven't speaking entrepreneurs and part of the thing you'll note is that you know 2/3 of the way through we present three business ideas for how we're gonna make money because of which we had no revenue when we were pitching LinkedIn Series B and now of course speaking as entrepreneur entrepreneur when you present three options like that what it really means is we don't know right like we're could be one of these three and see we got some good ideas and it could possibly work now what you'll notice when you look at those three as none of those three are actually where the majority of LinkedIn revenue comes from because and this is the flexibility which is what happened is I thought if you'd asked me during LinkedIn Series B what was going to be the revenue model that would be the driving model that would make LinkedIn successful I thought it was individual subscription that was going to be expensed so you had to make it expensable but it be an individual individuals hiring managers business Delmon people etc who would be driving their actual use within two weeks of when we launched the subscription model we started getting inquiries from companies that said hey we'd like to buy your corporate product and we like okay well that's interesting I mean we knew that we'd get to it but we thought it would be like five years in the future and so we did a paper mock-up of the corporate product we were working on right that we were not working on to be super clear and we hired a salesperson and we sent the salesperson out to say here's the product we're working on would you buy this and the salesperson came back said okay I've talked to you know thirty people and and like 20-plus of them are interested in buying this product and so we said okay let's pivot the company right to build that is our revenue product and that's the thing that ended up being the majority of the revenue even to now
title: How We Found our Business Model at LinkedIn - Reid Hoffman
author: Entrepreneurs First

key_facts: LinkedIn Series B pitch presented three business ideas with no current revenue
The three business ideas were not the source of LinkedIn's majority revenue
Initial belief was that individual subscription would drive LinkedIn's success
Corporate product was not actively being developed during Series B pitch
Inquiries from companies about corporate product began shortly after subscription launch
A mock-up of the corporate product was created for sales outreach
Salesperson reported over 20 out of 30 prospects expressed interest in buying the product
Company pivoted to build the corporate product as the primary revenue driver
Corporate product became the majority revenue source for LinkedIn
Pivot occurred within weeks of subscription model launch
key_opinions: Presenting three options signals uncertainty about the correct revenue path
The shift to corporate product was a strategic necessity despite initial plans
The speed of corporate interest was surprising and unexpected
The pivot was justified by strong market demand from enterprises
Individual subscriptions were initially prioritized but proved less impactful
key_datapoints: 2/3 of the way through LinkedIn Series B, three business ideas were presented
20+ out of 30 company prospects expressed interest in the corporate product
Pivot occurred within two weeks of subscription model launch
Corporate product became the majority of LinkedIn's revenue
Expected timeline for corporate product development was five years
